channel.description: Computer science student and machine learning enthusiast.

item.title: DeepFake Art
item.description:
Below you can see two faces on the left and right. Each of them were generated by a neural network. You can play around with the features of the images by using the sliders and choosing the corresponding latent dimensions.

# of Images:
Latent Dimension Latent Dimension

Inspired by the realistic-looking fake faces generated by Nvidia, I took it upon myself to use deep learning to synthesize fake faces as they would appear in fine art.

Getting the Data

Before we can delve into the details of model implementation we should discuss how the data was gathered to train the models in the first place.

I combined the dataset of paintings from two Kaggle datasets Painter by Numbers and Art Images.

Using OpenCV, I made a face extracting pipeline in Python. The pipeline uses a pre-trained ResNet model to detect faces. Those faces are then saved in a specified directory.

Running this on the two datasets above results in a dataset of 28k images of faces. That is then split into 21k training samples and 7k testing samples.

This amount of data is a fourth of Nvidia’s FFHQ dataset for GANs (70k) and an order of magnitude off of the standard CelebA dataset (200k images).

Background

There are two popular generative machine learning approaches: Variational AutoEncoders (VAE) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN).

AutoEncoders (AE) take some sort of data (in this case an image) and attempt to reconstruct it from a lower representation space.

The encoder portion of AEs takes some input and maps it to the lower dimensional representation; the decoder then takes the representation and attempts to reconstruct the image.

Source: Francois Chollet, Keras Blog

AEs potential to generate never-before-seen data comes from the variational variant of AutoEncoders. VAEs compress the input sample to a probability distribution. A random point is then sampled from the distribution to reconstruct the original input. By randomly sampling points and passing them through the decoder, we can generate new images.

Our other model architecture, GANs, are composed of two models in one: the generator and the discriminator. The generator component takes as input random noise and generates a data sample. The discriminator takes in a sample and then outputs whether it is a real image (i.e. from the training set) or fake (i.e. created by the generator). The generator attempts to trick the discriminator by generating more and more realistic samples.

GAN using MNIST Digit Dataset. Source: Naoki Shibuya, Towards Data Science



Let’s now look at the specific papers this project implemented. This is where things get a bit more technical.

Deep Feature Consistent VAE

In the paper Deep Feature Consistent Variational Autoencoder, Hou et. al introduce a replacement for reconstruction loss in VAEs which “(enforces) deep feature consistency between the input and the output”. The paper suggests using a model pre-trained on a similar task (e.g. image classification in this case) to extract high-level features from both the input images and generated images during training. The difference between the two is the feature perceptual loss.

DFC VAE model. Source: Hou et. al



Using Keras, I built a VAE with an input shape of 64x64 and a latent dimension of 100. The loss network is the 10 top layers of the VGG19 network trained on the Imagenet dataset.

During training, the learning rate of the model is halved during a plateau. The model is trained on the complete data set for 30 epochs.

Training of DFC-VAE

The results of all this training are really decent for such a relatively small dataset.

Images on the left show an image from the dataset. The right is it's reconstruction through the DFC VAE

StyleGAN

The paper A Style-Based Generator Architecture for Generative Adversarial Networks introduces a GAN architecture that allows for more control of the generator.

The difference between a plain GAN and a StyleGAN is the architecture of the generator. They tweak the generator to feed the random noise into an intermediary latent space. This latent space can be manipulated in the same way as the VAE’s.

The latent space is then ‘injected’ into the synthesis part of the network using AdaIN.

Generator portion of StyleGAN, Source: Karras et. al

Just like the DFC VAE, the StyleGAN is trained using images of 64x64 but with a latent space of 128 dimensions. A huge difference between the two models is the computational complexity of training GANs. Training the DFC VAE for 30 epochs took ~25 minutes. To train the GAN until it achieved good results took ~400k epochs and 36 hours training on a GPU cluster.

You can see examples of that in the application above. The results are truly amazing considering the small size of the dataset!

The great thing about the latent representation is that it allows us to tune samples. We are at liberty to choose any of the 128 dimensions of the latent space and adjust it to our liking. Different dimensions might encode different features of the face. We can also find the interpolation between two random faces to truly see the generative power of the StyleGAN.

Web App

I decided to build a Flask API on top of the StyleGAN model in order to make this project much more interactive.

API calls are made from a JavaScript/jQuery client I’ve developed for this website.

The application was then made into a Docker image and deployed on AWS Elastic Beanstalk for hosting.

Conclusion

This was the longest project I’ve undertaken and really inspired me to further pursue my self-study in machine learning. It opened my eyes to the incredibly vast research around GANs and all the crazy forms they can take.

The weights for the DFC VAE are available here and for the StyleGAN right here.

Thanks for sticking around until the end! 😄

item.title: Predicting Biology with Machine Learning
item.description:
Over the summer, I had the amazing opportunity of working as a research intern at Lewis Lab in the Center for Neural Dynamics.

Background

Weakly Electric Fish are often studied in neuroscience as their complex nervous system has fascinated many scientists. These types of fish usually live in very turbid and muddy waters. These species are specially adapted for this environment as they utilize a sense other than their sight to perceive their environment. Through continually generating an electric field around them and by measuring disturbances in that field, the weakly electric fish gain an electric sense.

The Goal

Use machine learning tools to determine the type of environment a fish is placed in by tracking its movement.

The Project

Before getting into the details of the machine learning portion of the project, let’s delve into how the data was processed.

Getting the Data

I received the data as a directory full of CSVs. The files were simply rows (x,y) coordinates representing the location the fish over time. Due to a lack of data, I decided on just training the models on two different environment types: high and low water conductivity. To actually train and test models with this data we need to have it all uniform and standardized.

To do so I made a Scikit-Learn pipeline to create the dataset. It reads the CSV files, divides them into equally sized chunks of 999 (x,y). Most could be divided by 999, if not, the pipeline used mean imputation to fill in the rest of the values. Finally, the data is then standardized to a mean of 0 and unit variance. This allows for gradient descent to converge much faster.

The final result is a dataset of 53k samples. A decent amount but not enough for the traditional train/test/validation split most machine learning projects use.

Instead, I settled on using K-fold cross-validation with k=10. To train the models, you divide the dataset into 10 separate partitions. You then iterate through the partitions and retain one group as the validation set and the rest as the training set. You record the evaluation scores and discard the model at each iteration. After tweaking the hyperparameters and retraining the models, you train the final model on the complete dataset.

A data sample after passing through the pipeline

That’s enough about the data, let’s go into detail about model implementation.

The Models

I decided on using the two common deep learning architectures for sequence processing: 1-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Networks (1D-CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM). All the models were implemented in Keras.

1D-CNN

ConvNets are a class of neural networks that learn groups of filters. They are usually used for image tasks. Their 1-Dimensional variant allows for sequence processing.

LSTM

LSTMs have been one of the most revolutionary machine learning models for sequence processing. They are composed of LSTM cells with a hidden state that can process data sequentially.

Results

After several iterations of the model architecture and hyperparemeter optimization using GridSearchCV, the final trained model was an LSTM model with a validation accuracy of ~85%. This makes it clear that machine learning models can predict rather accurately the type of environment these animals are placed in using only trajectory information.

item.title: Flow
item.description:
You know when you’re hungry on campus and just want to get a bite to eat without waiting in a long line? Yeah, we made an app for that.

The Problem

At our local uOttaHack Day, my team wanted to solve the problem of busyness. Often times on campus, it is quite random which food places and study spots are overcrowded. We wanted to develop an app that would allow us to make an informed decision on where to go before even leaving our seats.

The Solution

To count the number of people in a location, we set up a node that counted nearby MAC addresses. By subtracting the addresses that correspond to university networking equipment, we can get an estimate of the number of people at the location.

This data is gathered and sent to be stored in a database at set intervals. The web and mobile app then query the database to display the information to the users.

The mobile apps were built using Flutter and written in Dart. This allowed for fast prototyping and cross-platform support.

Conclusion

Our project ended up winning first place at the hackathon! I’m extremely proud of me and my team.

item.title: Android Calculator
item.description: This is a calculator android app written in Android SDK and Java. This is a project I worked on while learning android development.

item.title: Personal Website
item.description:
Woah! This is pretty meta.

This website was written using Jekyll and the static pages were written in a combination of Markdown, HTML, and CSS.

All of the interactive portions of the website (eg, DeepFake Art) are written using JS and JQuery.
